name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Autistic fiction-writing hacks:

1) Music playlist aligned to my main character's personality.
2) Chewelry for stimming.
3) Keeping a digital photo book of inspiration related to my special interests.

Three. Two. One. Chapter done!

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: As a speaking Autistic person, I do not know what it would be like to seek therapy as a nonspeaking Autistic person. I imagine it would be very difficult, and I hope to learn more on this topic.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
I can only imagine that an Autistic therapist would understand Autism-related struggles without an explanation of Autism traits.

I can only imagine how freeing it might be to not have to explain my pain, but to receive immediate empathy from a therapist.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
...crying and kicking and completely beside myself. I was miserable, but no one would understand. I knew my therapist would ask, "Why was this so important to you?"

So, I stuffed the pain inward, and I got on my therapy call. I said, "I've had a bad day. I'm working too much."

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
As a result, I often hide (mask) my Autistic struggles from therapists, because I don't feel as though they are ready for it.

For example, 10 minutes before a therapy session, I nearly had a meltdown because I missed an opportunity related to my special interest, I was...

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
I am a Black multiracial, queer, Autistic woman. I have become a teacher many times to my therapists in order to explain why a situation was hard for me. 

15+ minutes spent on explanations, when I was hoping for validation or another perspective.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
As an Autistic person, I often fall in-and-out of therapy and therapists. This is not ideal, and I don't enjoy this at all. It just is.

Why? Because I reach a point where my therapist cannot comprehend my problems, and then I become an educator in my therapy sessions.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Neurodivergent folks need neurodivergent mental health therapists.

Seeking to be seen and understood by a therapist who struggles to see and understand my challenges is not therapeutic. It is work.

description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Let me be clear, Autism Awareness is a stepping-stone, a first step, a starting off point.

Society cannot stop at Awareness.
We can't even stop at Acceptance.
Let's strive for the long-term: Inclusion.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Many folks have to relearn Autism. They have to become aware that they have been fed misinformation.

Fighting for acceptance from folks that misunderstand me at the baseline is a recipe for pain on my end of that power dynamic.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: As an Autistic person, I don't believe someone can accept me, much less include me, if they aren't aware of what it really means to be Autistic.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
While I'm rooting for Autism Acceptance, I don't believe Awareness has been achieved.

Awareness is knowing what Autism is and what our traits are.

It's realizing that children/adults of all genders & races are Autistic.

It's recognizing speaking and nonspeaking experiences ğŸ§µ

@ItsEmilyKaty My response to sensory overstimulation varies, depending on which sense is overstimulated and for how long. Sensory overload may cause me:

1) Physical pain (muscles, eyes, ears, head)
2) Brain pain
3) Nausea & disorientation
4) Irritability or anxiety
5) Fatigue or restlessness

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
At the end of the day, for autistics (and others):

1) Special interest activities are better.
2) Friends don't force friends to mask.
3) Online friendships are valid.
4) 1 real friend overrides 50 fake ones.
5) My social life is my business.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
The truth is: Autistics matter. Our true selves matter. Our authentic personalities and interests are beautiful, too.

Yet, we are fighting for society to not only recognize us (awareness) but accept us (not change us). And then, one day, include us.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
As an autistic person, if I go to an event I don't like or have no interest in just to "make friends," I will mask. I'll try to be someone that others will like instead of who I truly am.

And I have been praised for ignoring my needs, wants, interests, & personality for others.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Coercing autistic individuals to attend activities, clubs, and parties in the name of "making friends" when they genuinely have no interest in (and perhaps dread) the event is not okay.

It teaches us that fake friendship is more important than emotional & bodily autonomy.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Sometimes, overload in one type can cause us to be more sensitive to overloading in another type. 

For example, when I experience social overload, I am much more sensitive to information overload.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: The four types of overload can occur one at a time or at the same time, and may require different types of self-care strategies in order to recover.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Autistic overload can be more than sensory. In fact, there are four main types of overload:

1) Sensory
2) Social
3) Informational
4) Emotional

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
4) Tokenizing of Autistics abounds.

Suddenly, organizations that use ableist practices want to hire (or request free labor from) Autistics in order to check off a diversity box. Not all orgs are like this, but it's enough that it hurts.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
3) "Light it up blue" is an unfortunate tradition during this month. The color blue is associated with Autism because of the gendered notion that Autism is a condition that only impacts boys.

Many Autistics and allies choose to wear #RedInstead.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
2) The puzzle piece is everywhere, and Autistics are expected to be happy about it!

The puzzle piece is the infantile symbol originally used by Autism Speaks, a problematic organization that paints Autism as a tragedy. Many Autistics don't relate to the idea that we're a puzzle.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
1) Autism Acceptance/Awareness Month was not created for Autistics. It was a day, week, month, whatever that was originally designed by and for those who "speak for" Autistics.

It's a whole month during which Autistics have to fight to have our own experiences centered.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
I'm willing to wager that I'm not the only Autistic that's feeling increased anxiety levels as April approaches.

Autism Acceptance Month is a wild ride. And here's some reasons why: ğŸ§µ

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: I fully recognize that this can get complicated when we view conversations through an "intent vs. impact" lens. The crossroad of neurodiversity and mainstream inclusive practices is a complex topic that I am happy to invite into this conversation.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: The next time we fear that we made a social mistake, we as autistics can remind ourselves that our well-meant actions, good intentions, and kind gestures are never mistakes, even if someone tries to ableist-ically convince us that we're broken.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
For Autistics, a masked/camouflaged life means setting a life goal of making zero social mistakes. 

An unmasked life is only possible if our social mistakes are no longer seen as mistakes but as moments of two-way miscommunication. (see: Double Empathy Problem)

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Autistic individuals & autistic thinking aren't broken. We aren't mistakes. 

When an NT does something that I can't make sense of, I take it upon myself to understand the NT's perspective. I don't assume their entire existence is a mistake that requires masking to cover it up.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
@commaficionado The recovery phase after a meltdown is often the most fragile state. Yet, during this time, so many autistics are targeted for explanations of our "behavior" or overloaded with "advice" on how to handle our "anger."

But all of this can trigger another meltdown!

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Here are some tips for coping with sounds from electrical appliances: https://t.co/tevplqXFK2

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: The non-stop din of electrical appliances may remain a backdrop of all we do. For auditorily-sensitive autistics, these sounds can cause migraines, irritability, as well as aches and pains. We may become accustomed to the pain, but we do not become desensitized to the noise.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: While allistic individuals may hear electrical sounds when someone points them out, they can generally ignore the sounds. This is due to habituation, or the physiological process of diminishing our responses to stimuli. Autistics, however, don't usually habituate in the same way.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Autistics can often hear the sounds of electrical appliances that others' tune out. 

It is not in our imagination.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: "Having meltdowns is what I do in order to get what I want!" said no autistic person ever.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Autistics need understanding and support after meltdowns, not punishment. We need help making a plan, understanding our triggers, and finding supportive spaces. We do not need more shaming.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: As a kid and as an adult, I have often been made to feel at fault for my meltdowns. This led me to have cycles of meltdowns, days in a row, because my fear of upsetting people with my meltdowns would compound my other meltdown triggers.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Punishing an autistic person for a meltdown will not prevent a future meltdown.

Demanding answers for an autistic person's meltdown immediately after the crisis can cause another meltdown.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: @fibonacci_rocks I have often wondered if shutdowns are perceived as anxiety and/or panic attacks, and autistic burnout is misconstrued as depression.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
When I stim dance I am personally tapping into audiomotor, or sound-to-kinetics, synesthesia. 

Basically, sounds often cause involuntary movements in my body. I hear a sound or a part of a song, and my body responds immediately without my control or intentional thought.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Synesthesia is when you experience one of your senses through the other, often at the same time.

Examples: Smell sounds, taste sights, feel smells, hear touch.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Stimming is repetitive motions or behaviors that may represent or regulate sensory input or emotions.

Ex: nail biting, singing, jumping, flapping, leg shaking, insert your stims here.

Stimming often taps into the 8 senses. So it makes sense that it could connect to synesthesia.

https://t.co/az9vlHhyop

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Basically, most people seem to recognize that the 8-hour workday is wildly exhausting. So, they add in social chatter and coffee breaks.

But if a disabled person requests an accommodation to work, say, 3 hours a day, that's considered "unreasonable."

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
In an ableist society where our worth is often measured by whether or not we can obtain and maintain a full-time white collar job, I struggle to wrap my head around the fact that:

The average employee is productive for only 3 hours in their work day.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Example #2: A long time ago (pre-Autism Dx), I was in a mental health facility. I was asked if I would like treatment for anxiety OR depression. I requested treatment for anxiety. I was told that if I didn't comply with treatment for depression, I could not leave the facility.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
I'll give two examples:

Example #1: I purchased a dress from a small business. I was told I could provide 19 measurments or 3 measurements. I requested the 3 measurments option. I was then badgered for two days that I should not go with that option. I broke down in tears.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Have you ever been given two options by a non-autistic, and you choose an option, and then you're told, "No, you should pick the other option."

This almost always causes me to meltdown and cry.

Why was I presented with two options in the first place?

tweet: P.S. Some autistics don't like fiction. Some do. Sounds a lot like PEOPLE.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
As an undiagnosed autistic seeking self-understanding, I once believed the lie that I couldn't be autistic because I enjoyed fiction.

Fiction connected to my special interests. Fiction taught me about the world that I couldn't understand. Fiction was my escape from ableism.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Burn the stereotype that autistics don't like, appreciate, or understand fiction to the ground.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Inclusion takes both work and mindset shifts. There are no inclusive shortcuts.

And I often notice that the biggest pushback against inclusion is the false concern that true, authentic inclusion will somehow harm those in power.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
I don't want to be invited into unwelcoming spaces. I'm not grateful for these invitations.

I want spaces to be reorganized to be actually inclusive. I want marginalized people to be involved and in charge of redesigning these spaces.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Inclusivity involves looking at a space and seeing all the ways it's set up to benefit those in power.

And then redesigning and resetting that space to support, affirm, and amplify marginalized folks.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Inclusivity isn't just inviting people.
It isn't just about giving space to speak.
It isn't just listening either.

tweet: A phrase that I repeat frequently is "I just want to go home." Whenever I'm upset, stressed, frustrated, overloaded: "I just wanna go home." I started saying, "I just want to go home," when I was home.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Examples of my echolalia are that I repeat words that for some reason just trigger this joy in me. Someone said, "Plop!" and all I could do was say plop and make up plopping words. It was actually my way of engaging with that person.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
According to WebMD, echolalia is the repetition or imitation of sounds, phrases, and words. 

Most people think that echolalia is bad and should be stopped. How much you want to bet it's because they think it's annoying.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Most people when they look at me would have no idea that I am: 1) autistic , and 2) have echolalia.

In other words, autism & echolalia isn't a look. Here's what echolalia is, with examples:

Echolalia isn't random or meaningless. Echolalia is a form of autistic communication. ğŸ§µ

tweet:
Some common meltdown triggers include: sensory overload, too much socializing, routine changes, and being misunderstood.

Even more, meltdown triggers and feelings differ for each autistic.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: After my meltdowns subside, I am drained, dazed, and relieved. But I may feel afraid that others will punish me for my meltdowns. This is terrifying, especially because my meltdowns are out of my control.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: My autistic meltdowns feel like electricity is shocking my body, skin, brain, and ears. I pace, throw things, scream, and cry as a way to push out all the painful electricity.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Non-autistics can only see autistic meltdowns. They can only guess what meltdowns feel like for us.

Many autistics experience meltdowns, but that doesn't mean all our meltdowns feel the same.

What do your autistic meltdowns feel like?

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Task initiation is a consistent struggle for me. Here is the method I personally use for task initiation (followed by an example). It involves making a mental movie, or visualizing the many details of a big task. https://t.co/q3xyWVf9Xx

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: When we have a big task to accomplish, autistics can feel guilty that we can't start it at all. These feelings of guilt may throw us further into imbalance. As such, we are even more likely to return to our high-intensity interests in order to cope and regulate.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Starting a task is difficult. It requires breaking down an activity into small pieces. Tasks are usually made up of multiple tasks. In fact, tasks often have multiple starting points. So, in order to initiate an activity, we actually have to start multiple times.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Task initiation is an executive functioning skill that involves knowing how to begin an activity. For many autistics, getting lost in the midst of a task comes naturally, but actually kicking off the task is the hardest part.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Let's talk about task initiation. ğŸ§µ

Task initiation is hard for many autistics, whose brains may be geared toward staying in the midst of a few high-intensity interests.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)

tweet: Instead of "targeting" so-called social "deficits" of autistic children, maybe the narrow majority in our society should put the target on our failing systems. Where and how is money really being spent? Where are people's true hearts when considering social differences?

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Unless we are mimicking for fun, autistic mimicking often results in deterioration of our mental health. While social mimicking may be a coping skill born out of necessity, the real change needs to happen within society: authentic autistic inclusion.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: It is important to note that mimicry in friendships and relationships is not intentional deception. In fact, autistics are often encouraged or forced to not act "autistically," or else face social rejection or exclusion.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Autistics may mimic people who we want to begin a friendship or relationship with. We do this in the hopes of being liked. This mimicry isn't the same as finding things in common. It's forcing ourselves to mimic the interests of another person in an attempt to be accepted.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Autistic mimicry can lead to the full-time adoption of a persona. These personas may include elements from beloved fictional characters or real people that we feel are socially-confident. However, these personas may take over, and we may lose our true selves beneath these masks.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: At times, autistics may mimic real people that we like. We may also mimic celebrities, TV or movie personalities, and video game or book characters. If our special interests revolve around a fictionalÂ world, we may mimic the characters within that world. This is often enjoyable.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Mimicry is different from echolalia, yet related. Echolalia is often an unintentional repetition of specific words and sounds; mimicry is generally done on a more conscious level. Mimicry can include the repetition of specificÂ catchphrases as a means of scripting conversations.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Autistic mimicry can be defined as copying and adopting the speech patterns, dress, and general personality of a real or fictional person. It goes beyond trying out popularÂ trends. Instead, autisticÂ mimicry revolves around building a persona. https://t.co/z0zhzZwOVh

@NeuroRebel Whoa! I just tweeted about this. That's so weird how this sort of thing happens. 

And masking is a tool of assimilation used against autistics by an ableist society.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Amidst all the talk about how to unmask, why to unmask, whether or not it's safe to unmask, I just wanted to pause and say that loud and clear.

Masking is enforced through ableism.
Masking is a tool of assimilation.
Masking is not an autistic person's fault.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)

tweet: Masking exists because society is not comfortable with Autism. Masking and unmasking is not an autistic person's responsibility or a right of passage into self-acceptance.

@LowkeyBrilliant I didn't travel that year, not even by car. I got both vaccine shots by Feb 2021. 

I go out now, out to eat, to see my friends. I wear my mask outside and ALWAYS on the train. I walk instead of taking public transport when I can. I try to work for home. I have a booster. [4/4]

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
@LowkeyBrilliant After late May, I only saw the same 3 people for "socializing." I then only went to outdoor events, MASKED UP. I wore a mask for pretty much everything.

I worked from home till September, then worked under extreme sanitizing and air flow conditions. [3/]

tweet: @LowkeyBrilliant Once NYC went into lockdown, I did NOT leave my apartment for a month. Not even to stand on the patio. I only left after that because my partner has asthma, so I did the grocery shopping. I did not order takeout or do anything but a short walk outside until late May. [2/]

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: There is a frustrating element to erasing functioning labels. Removing high/low functioning & supports labels makes it very difficult for autistics & their loved ones to advocate. Without specific words for our experiences, it is difficult to access care, supports, and community.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Now, high/low supports and high/low functioning labels have transformed to describe whatever any person means in any given moment. And generally, those using these labels are speaking on behalf of autistics or an autistic person.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
High-functioning versus low-functioning was originally used to describe IQ differences among autistics. IQ is a poor (and biased) measure of intellect and an even
poorer measure of mental, emotional, and physical needs.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Since ASD is a neurotype, then just like neurotypical individuals, autistics have a variety of support needs that may or may not change over time or in different circumstances. This is sometimes referred to as a dynamic disability.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Autism is a spectrum.
Binary (high/low functioning) labels cannot be replaced with other binary (high/low supports) labels, because these terms cannot describe a spectrum of experiences. In fact, they are based on stereotypes generalizations.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Instead of high/low functioning or high/low supports, we might refer to our actual supports.

Here are some graphics that may help: https://t.co/4mOfJ1cEax

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Functioning labels and high/low supports labels do not adequately represent autistic experiences. They represent non-autistic perceptions of Autism. ğŸ§µ

tweet:
And I will keep reclaiming my stimming.
Because not stimming has never helped me.

Stimming heals me.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
CW: Self-injurious stims.

I have had self-injurious stims in the past that I replaced with the healthy stims that others shut down when I was a kid. I have been pulled away from, "or distracted" by neurotypical expectations because of my need to stim.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: I auditorily stimmed by listening to this song, Hatsukoi (First Love)" by Utada Hikaru on repeat. And then I began 5o stim dance the smallness away. Despite what the world may tell me, I am different not less.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: I started this day feeling very small. I was growing smaller, weighed down by my differences. I love being different, but I am exhausted by feeling small. Instead making myself into something I am not, I leaned into my Autism.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Stimming isn't wrong.
Stimming isn't random.
Stimming isn't meaningless.

Stimming heals me. https://t.co/iUPO2Pi8sY

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Sometimes, I see autistics make self-deprecating comments about so-called info dumping.

The truth is: We're being shamed for our monotropic brains. We're being shamed for our passions. We're being told we are inherently bad.

And we're being encouraged to internalize that shame.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: I've found that info dumping isn't always about those one hour special interests share alouds. If autistics talk for 10+ minutes about our special interests but do this multiple times over a series of hangouts, we're often automatically considered info dumpers.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
I've heard it said that people won't tell me to stop talking about my special interest because they don't want to hurt my feelings.

So instead of just asking me to stop, they made fun of me, called me and my "info dumping" annoying behind my back. Regardless of my feelings.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Yes, there are times & places when I share my special interest for long periods of time.

Yes, there are people who don't want to listen to me talk about my SpIn for an hour or more.

But there's a neurotypical social power dynamic going on here:

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Most recently, info dumping is used to describe autistic individuals when we talk about our special interests.

Apparently, we don't share our passions. We don't describe our passions. We don't teach about our passions.

We info dump.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
According to Dictionary[dot]com, info dumping is providing a large quantity of backstory or background information all at once. It is a slang term that almost always has a negative connotation.

The term has no clear origin but may originate from copy/paste responses online.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Allistic people have said to me, "I love hearing things that other people are passionate about!" But once I start talking, I eventually recognize the social cues I've been taught to memorize: Raised eyebrows in shock, eyes darting away in boredom, and making excuses to walk away.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: I am also a little afraid of myÂ special interests, because other people have shown me that having special interests is not right. Or maybe I'm afraid of those who say, "Tell me about your interest!" Most of the time, they have no idea how deep the well of my special interest is.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: My special interests are what rejuvenate me. When I speak about them, I am filled with the purest joy. When I research them, I feel at peace. When I am confused about a topic, my special interests often help me to make sense of it.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
If I stop talking aboutÂ my autistic special interests for the sake of social rules, I start masking. 

This masking runs so deep that I actually have a list of "socially acceptable" pretend interests. I've spent way too much time researching these allistic-approved interests.

description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: @ZeroWrites When I was younger, I would reinvent my handwriting in order to mimic my peers who I saw as social models. Now, I just in whatever way is most comfortable for me.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Everyone watched me take a bite of the pie that made me want to gag. I chewed & swallowed. They asked, "Don't you like it?" I hate lying, but under their harsh eyes, I knew I had to say, "Yes, I do." They clapped as I hid my tears. I had performed well for them. They approved.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: After dinner came pumpkin pie. I didn't like pie. The texture was sticky but bready and mushy, and I didn't like that mix. My parents never made me eat pie, but suddenly, at this big family Thanksgiving, I was told, "Be respectful and try your aunt's pie. You'll like it."

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Around the kids my age, I had to pretend to be cool, or not be a "loudmouth" or "annoying" as I was so often called. Looking back, I realize I was scared of all the pressure, sounds, smells, and people. I was looking forward to dinner being over.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: But then, when I was around 8 years old, I went to Thanksgiving dinner in another state with over 30 extended family. I had to sit a certain way, smile and nod to adults talking about me like I wasn't there.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: As a child, I spent Thanksgiving with my immediate family. No visitors, no travels, no major routine changes. I loved Thanksgiving. I got to eat my favorite mushy food textures. I wasn't forced to eat textures that I didn't like. It was like any other day, but a little special.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)

tweet:
Fear & stigma stops autistics & disabled folx from asking for the supports we need to access unsupportive environments on an equitable basis. 

For me, this means I need society to provide authentic access. Also, I am learning to let go of internalized ableism and ask for help.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
The voice in my head tells me to grin and bear it all day, every day. This voice will go so far as to say, "If you can grin and bear it, then you don't need any accommodations."

This voice is internalized ableism. This voice is lying.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: There's this voice in my head. It comes out when I think to seek an accommodation or access. This voice says, "You aren't disabled enough." This voice makes me scared that people will say I'm faking my disability.

description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
I almost had a fairness meltdown yesterday.

Why? Ableism. I felt the weight of how far we have to go to inclusion & accessibility. It isn't fair. It isn't right. It's clearly evil. Yet so many people in power refuse to acknowledge ableism or put in the effort to change things.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Many autistics plainly see faults in society, and we passionately refuse to be passive about it. However, when allistics insist that we "let go of/ignore" these societal flaws, we may feel despair. At times, we may have what I am calling "fairness meltdowns."

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Autistic "black-and-white" thinking is often founded upon ethics and personal research into important topics. In other words, autistics tend to be ethically-minded, justice-centered, and seekers of fairness.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Black-and-white thinking is often used to describe a common autistic trait. This specific trait revolves around autistics taking a stance and sticking to it. While some refer to this as rigidity, autistics may not experience it as such.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Sometimes so-called "black and white" thinking can cause autistic meltdowns. ğŸ§µ

The ambiguity of "reasonable" accommodations is systemically intentional. (And rooted in capitalism, of course.)

It has caused me to not ask for what I needed out of fear of immediate rejection. Self-advocacy isn't easy.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Autistics and disabled folx are told we can request "reasonable" accommodations...

So what exactly is a "reasonable" accommodation? How can we trust those who are not disabled to determine what is "reasonable" about our right to access?

@AutSciPerson Absolutely unacceptable. Disabled people are not another department's "problem." We are not buck to be passed. Our needs are not reasonable or unreasonable. We are not at inconvenience.

And we are so often inconvenienced by abled individuals.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
To receive accommodations, disabled folx (autistics included) bear the burden of mapping out our needs. We are also pressured into giving the rationale for supports. By law, we shouldn't have to disclose our diagnosis, but we may be manipulated into doing so. 

This is ableism.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
@BeingCharisBlog I started wearing glasses in kindergarten. I could tell my mom was disappointed for vanity reasons, and so to this day, I typically only wear contacts out of shame around looking less attractive in glasses.

tweet: "Everyone's a little autistic" centers the NT experience. It defines ASD as a set of quirks & not a neurotype of its own.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Allistics insisting that they experience the same struggles as autistics causes harm by:
-Denying the ASD experience and defining us in NT terms
-Implying that autistics are exaggerating their struggles
-Promoting a "just deal w/ it" mentality that leads to a lack of ASD supports https://t.co/7DM501309b

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Hidden in the phrase is an attempt at empathy. It tries to highlight that "we're all the same; I don't see you as different from me." I might tell an allistic that I struggle with small talk. This person may reply, "Lots of people dislike small talk. That's not weird."

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: "Everyone's a little autistic" is a phrase typically used by allistics in an attempt to build a connection between autistic & allistic experiences. However, instead of creating a bridge, this phrase often actually alienates autistics.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
"Everyone's a little autistic" is the opposite of putting oneself in another person's shoes. Yet, allistics tend to believe that the phrase is empathetic. 

But telling an autistic that their difficult experiences are just like those of allistics isn't empathetic. ğŸ§µ

Autistics deserve happiness.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
I grew up saying, "I don't need to be happy. I don't care about happiness."

I was proud of this, because I had already internalized, as an undiagnosed autistic, that my societal worth was measured by my productive output, not by society's perception of value.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: What might my emotional journey have looked like if stimming, echolalia, and autistic expressions of feelings had been shown to me in picture books, classroom songs, and feelings charts? Inclusive education is essential for autistics.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
As I reclaim my personal autistic emotional expressions, I can better recognize the emotions of others. I bounce when I'm happy. That is the same feeling that others might express by smiling. 

I have a frame of reference now, and it's made all the difference.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Alexithymia is real, but for me, it was a mislabel. It's not that I can't recognize my emotions but that I mistaught my emotions. I was always taught allistic emotional expression.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
At first, alexithymia, or the inability to recognize my emotions in myself or others, felt like good way to describe my autistic experiences. Until I started taking off the mask.

I reclaimed stimming. I reclaimed echolalia. I reclaimed my authentic facial expressions.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
I spent hours staring at these emotions charts. I memorized and copied them. I thought emotions were something to mimic. A set of vocabulary I needed to burn into my mind. 

Then, I learned a word for my experience that is often used to describe autistics: Alexithymia.

tweet: Studies* have shown that disclosure & non-disclosure of ASD has negative impacts on autistics' mental health. In other words, autistics experience stress, anxiety, & feelings of exclusion regardless of whether we share with othersÂ that we are autistic. https://t.co/l8IUysNf1u

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Coming out as autisticÂ is a personal choice. Disclosure can lead to pros and cons. Even more, autistics often must determine whoÂ is "safe" to come out to. While our families and school communities may know that we are autistic, we may not have told our friends or our coworkers.

Until someone tells you that it's weird. Or annoying. Or an obsession.

Or until I realize that society is set up so that my special interests "get in the way" of allistic productivity.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: As we strive to promote neurodiversity and autism acceptance, autistics also need access to supports and coping methods. We are still navigating today's difficulties as we look toward a more inclusive future.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Here are some tips for autistics who are navigating high-pressure social situations: https://t.co/wPqzaMUfwI https://t.co/4r3lKeaxVe

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Coming up with the "right" words at the right time takes up a lot brain space for autistics. Then, add sensory processing difficulties to the mix. It's a lot to manage.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: For example, ordering food at a restaurant may seem simple on the surface, but there are many social rules that can be debilitating for autistics: Don't ask the waiter too many questions; be ready to order in a specific timeframe; ask for the check at the right time.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Autistics are often forced to rely on pre-imagined scripts in high pressure situations. However, when we are under stress, our scripts become less accessible. Our brains go into overload, and we may shutdown, meltdown, or suffer from anxiety attacks.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Small talk may be hard for autistics, but high-stakes conversations are where the real nightmares begin. 

Think: public speaking, interviews, parties, ordering food or drinks, dates, etc. We have to speak quickly and speak well. Or else there may be immediate consequences.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: @babythedivine Grayromantic asexual. Just ate cantaloupe, strawberries, grapes, and a bread roll with hummus and vegan cheese spread.

tweet: @sunlytle Definitely not saying that ALL autistics dislike small talk. There are some autistics that have memorized small talk scripts or prefer small talk to intense talk (which can be more emotionally draining or result in rumination afterward).

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: If we embraced neurodiversity, we might recognize that there's more than one good way to respond to, "How are you?" As a society, we might do better to genuinely ask one another how we're doing. Otherwise, we may wind up lost in a sea of "I'm fine" when no one is actually fine.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Sadly, when autistics respond honestly to phatic greetings, like "How's it going?" we are often met with surprise. Or worse, we receive frowns of annoyance. This kind of response is deeply hurtful, because, well, all we did was answer the question!

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Autistics tend to prefer straightforward communication. We love to skip small talk & opt for intense discussion. When someone asks how we are doing, we might reply, "It's been a long day. I'm exhausted," or, "I'm really excited! I just learned about __."

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: "How are you" is an example of phatic language. Although it seems meaningless, non-autistics actually build social bonds with this kind of greeting. However, given that autistics bond & communicate differently from allistics, phatic language can be frustrating and even isolating.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Over time, I've scripted replies to, "How are you?" But no matter how many times I say, "Pretty good," "Doing all right," or just nod, I'm filled with panic. Does this person actually want to know how I'm doing? Why did they ignore me when I responded, "Fine. How about you?"

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Empty phrases like, "How are you?" are social nightmares for many autistics. Turns out, these confusing greetings are called phatic language, and they drive a wedge between autistic/allistic communication. ğŸ§µ

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)

tweet: @matt_saunders_ Yes! I hope for a day when we embrace neurodiversity and differences in self-expression!

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: @MPersephoneRose They make me uncomfortable too. Executive functioning differences are not the same as not wanting to do laundry because we wish someone else could do all the chores like when we were little kids.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Discussions around adulting often make light of societal & personal expectations to complete chores, run errands, & be independent. For autistics, these jokes may be relatable. Even so, executive functioning differences & lack of employment for autistics aren't funny.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: While not every autistic can mask, there may be dire consequences for not masking; behavior intervention, job loss, being perceived as a threat. Masking is damaging to mental health. It requires immense energy to maintain & causes meltdowns, shutdowns, & burnout.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: While masking or camouflaging autistic traits is referred to as a coping tool, it's better described as an assimilation tool. Autistics who are able to mask are usually encouraged to do so by allistics; it may even become compulsory.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: The role of being an adult inhibits freedom of expression. We see this in workplace dress, communication, & behavior codes. Since many autistics prefer alt styles & interests, we feel pressure to mask our traits to appear as mature adults. Otherwise, we may be deemed "immature."

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Adulting means to do things "like an adult." This new word carries an comedic message that adult life is boring & dull. The idea centers around completing mundane tasks/presenting professionally in the pursuit of independence.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Autistics need supports in navigating serious community issues. "Learning how to adult" isn't the same as needing access. Implying that autistics aren't adulting trivializes the issues we face.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾

Neurodiversity isn't ASD. ASD is part of Neurodiversity, and Neurodiversity also includes mental illnesses.

Destigmatizing ASD is directly tied to destigmatizing mental health disorders.

There must be space in neurodiversity for discussions around mental illness. Needs may be diverse. Supports may differ, but we're all striving for understanding & inclusion based upon our neurology.

#AskingAutistics: What was your most recent moment of autistic joy?

I'll start: I turned on a new song while doing some work on my laptop, and this song struck a chord in me. I immediately started stimming in my chair, and now I have a new stim song!

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: @goulcher I was undiagnosed autistic, and we were playing volleyball. Every time my team (not my friends) scored a point, I would happy stim by jumping up and down and lifting my arms. Then, my team all started imitating me and making fun of me. I never did that happy stim again.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: @shararehdrury The Avian Influenza or Bird Flu in the 90s. I was maybe seven years old.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Even discussing the male-bias of ASD diagnostic tools highlights another major issue in the ASD evaluation: the gendering of autism as binary.

The construct of "girl autism" and "boy autism" ignores the experiences of many trans and non-binary autistics.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: If it helps, here are a few ideas for growing our own ability to recognize our body cues & emotional states. (Taken from my most recent IG post: https://t.co/SbnjySLCsa) https://t.co/kMG6n7K7xY

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Many autistics have different body-based emotional cues than allistics. For example, when we're tired, we might start stimming instead of feeling sleepy. Since we are taught to expect neurotypical body cues, we may not be able to recognize our sense of interoception.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Interpreting our needs through our bodies' cues is helpful. If we understand our emotions as expressed through our internal state, we can take action to care for ourselves and regulate, in whatever way is natural for our autistic bodies.

https://t.co/ztf83PZAm5

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Interoception is the ability to connect internal cues to emotions. If we're stressed, our heart rate may change. We may sweat/shake. These cues also occur when we're excited, infatuated, or overtaxed. If the brain confuses the cues, we may think joy is fear, exhaustion is anger.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Interoception is one of the 8 senses. It's the ability of our bodies & brains to connect on an internal level. So, interoception is the key to recognizing the cues set off from our bodies' internal organs. Examples: Changing heart rate, toileting needs, hunger/thirst pangs, etc.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Instead of focusing on so-called deficits in autistic behavior, what if autistic support looked more closely at interoception?

Studies are showing a link between interoception & mental health. This is essential since interoception is often difficult for autistics to tap into.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Interoception is the ability to connect internal cues to emotions. If we're stressed, our heart rate may change. We may sweat/shake. These cues also occur when we're excited, infatuated, or overtaxed. If the brain confuses the cues, we may think joy is fear, exhaustion is anger.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: @Monet_AU Sitting on the floor or on yoga mats is so much more preferred! But a dining room table is much needed in my life for eating and working on my laptop!

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: @AutisticPb I believe ASD is genetic (not always inherited). Our sensory systems are often triggered by external factors; our health may be impacted by lack of supports & ableism. These issues may cause us to develop non-genetic comorbidities, caused by extreme stress & body/mental taxation.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: @drphilsbussyy The pervasive ableist belief that young people cannot be disabled is really damaging. It prevents disabled individuals from accessing early and/or onset supports. In turn, we are blocked from access to higher quality living.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: I am in no way trying to compare my experience with someone who cannot mask or "hide" their disability in order to gain access. Disability is complex. I don't want to push for my needs over the needs of another disabled person's. I hope to fight for collective disability justice.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: I am under considerable pressure to hide my disabilities at all times. Society values me insofar as I meet the standards they have set for the privilege of inclusion. If my mask slips, or if my pain becomes visible, I immediately lose value and suffer consequences.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: I'm autistic with a chronic pain condition. Invisible disability, to me, means that I can access spaces by masking my disabilities from those who would deny access to people with visible disabilities. However, there's a trade-off.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Having invisible disabilities (ASD and chronic pain) invites constant invalidation. Since I don't immediately "look" disabled, I am often told that I exaggerate my disabilities or do not have them.

In reality, I am often ignoring my own needs to make abled people comfortable. https://t.co/DcmohW0GtN

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: I will never claim to be exactly like another autistic or specific autistic child. Still, we may have more in common than some might think. But we wouldn't know, I guess, unless we communicated beyond social media!

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet:
Some of what I experienced as an autistic kid/teen:

Meltdowns 2-3/week
Late walking
Drank from bottles till I was 6
Sucked my fingers till I was 11
Self-injurious stimming
Rarely laughed
Picky eating
Weekly migraines & tummy aches
Shouting for talking
Monologuing
Poor hygiene

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Iâ€™m an autistic adult. It makes sense that I don't look like a child. I may be a different age/gender/race from a specific child, but I'm still autistic. When people look at me today, they cannot see my childhood. They cannot see my history or the range of needs I have/have had.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: It's possible. Autistics are all very different from each other. I'm also not a child. I'll never know what it is 100% like to be a different autistic person or to be a specific child's parent or teacher. Still, in the hopes of building a bridge, I have something to share.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: Re: "You're nothing like the autistic children I work with."

tweet: @Schereeya Stim dancing all the way! It combines visual, auditory, vestibular, and proprioceptive senses. It's my favorite way to express joy or to let off built up stress.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: As per @autistictic's caveat, I to clarify that melt/shutdowns aren't intentional communication. Autistics are not purposefully  a melting/shutting down to prove a point or get needs met. Communication can be body-up & unintentional, i.e. art, stims, body language, crying, etc.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: @autistictic @ZeroWrites I also don't believe that communication has to be intentional to be called communication, i.e. art, stimming, body language, crying, etc.

name: Lauren Melissa Ellzey (she/her)
description: #ActuallyAutistic Writer | Self-Advocate | LGBTQ+ | Dreamer & Fighter | Instructional Support Specialist | Check out my debut YA novel ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¾
tweet: @autistictic @ZeroWrites Thanks for clarifying this. My intention in the post is to discuss how the body is communicating autistic needs. I don't believe that melt/shutdowns are intentional communication.
